awd_titl_txt: OAC Core: Small: Collaborative Research: Data Provenance Infrastructure towards Robust and Reliable Data Sharing and Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapidly increasing number of interconnected devices and systems brings unprecedented collaborative opportunities between researchers, business partners, and healthcare organizations that can extend discoveries beyond those derivable from any single study. For instance, data sharing between various medical organizations can enhance understanding of the results from an individual clinical by polling of results from various trials from multiple organizations, and thus it enables extending the analysis of treatment options and accelerating biomedical research. While a vast amount of data collected from various sources brings us benefits, it imposes, at the same time, an important challenge of ensuring trustworthiness and quality of data due to the integration of disparate data from various sources. Furthermore, faulty, improperly configured, or broken sensors, as well as buggy or compromised data processing units, can severely affect the quality of data and the analyzed results. This project proposes to develop an infrastructure that provides robust, fine-grain, and end-to-end provenance for collaborative data sharing and analytics. The outcome of this research will directly serve as the foundation of trustworthy data sharing and analytic infrastructures by providing robust and attack/fault-resilient fine-grain provenance of the shared data by creating fine-grain end-to-end data provenance framework for diverse communication infrastructures.

In this project, the PIs will develop an end-to-end data provenance framework that provides robust and fine-grain data lineage for trustworthy data sharing and analytic infrastructures. First, they will develop a scalable and reliable infrastructure for collecting data provenance for distributed interconnected devices that can derive a concise provenance data in various environments of distributed devices (e.g., devices using diverse hardware and software platforms). Next, they will design and implement a framework to enable proper derivation and propagation of fine-grain provenance records for data sharing, processing, and analytics. It will provide services for provenance tracking as well as provenance record processing when the data are aggregated, analyzed, and processed (e.g., merge, split, duplicate, delete, extract, or statistical analytics). The PIs also plan to develop a system that can analyze and visualize the complete lineage of data to measure the quality of data and conduct various root cause analyses to identify the fundamental reasons behind data quality issues. The system will be capable of handling a large amount of data generated over a long period of time across multiple devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The rapidly increasing number of interconnected devices and systems enables unprecedented collaborative opportunities across various fields, encouraging more collaboration between researchers and business partners that can result in new findings or help better decision making. This project has addressed a critical need in the realm of interconnected devices and systems by establishing a robust, fine-grain, and end-to-end provenance infrastructure for collaborative data sharing and analytics. Specifically, we have established a framework to ensure the provenance of data, which includes tracking its creation, origin, and delivery paths, thereby enhancing trust and reliability in shared data across various fields.

 

Project Accomplishments:

Through out the project, we overcame significant challenges associated with maintaining detailed data provenance in complex communication environments, such as those using publish-subscribe messaging systems. Our efforts focused on developing a novel conversation inference method that models unique conversation relationships between machines (e.g., data producers and consumers), then leverages the models to infer provenance of messages at runtime, which are often complicated by diverse devices and communication infrastructures.

Simultaneously, we realized two major research thrusts. The first involved the development of an innovative technique for inferring machine-to-machine conversation relationships. This advancement played a crucial role in deploying models across various devices, ensuring the retrieval of trustworthy and efficient provenance. The second thrust focused on the development of a provenance-enabled communication framework. This framework is instrumental in supporting the derivation and propagation of detailed provenance records, a critical factor in maintaining data integrity. Furthermore, it provided essential services for tracking and processing these provenance records, particularly when original data underwent various reprocessing stages such as merging, splitting, duplicating, deleting, and extracting.

Overall, these accomplishments reflect our commitment to enhancing the security and reliability of data sharing and analytics in an increasingly interconnected digital world.

 

Broader Impacts and Educational Contributions:

The outcome of this project has significantly influenced the field of secure and trustworthy data sharing and analytics. By ensuring detailed and robust data provenance, we have enhanced the reliability of shared data. This achievement is not only a step forward in technological development but also contributes to the broader research and industrial communities. In addition to the technological impacts, this project has made substantial contributions to education and outreach. A new course focusing on security and privacy in data sharing and analytics was developed and offered to senior undergraduate and graduate students. This course represents a direct application of the project's findings and aims to educate the next generation of professionals in this crucial area. Furthermore, the research outcomes have been integrated into existing course materials and projects at both the University of Virginia and the University of Georgia, enriching the academic experience for students. Through established outreach programs, we have also engaged students from underrepresented groups, thereby promoting diversity in the field.

These educational initiatives, coupled with the project's technological achievements, underscore our commitment to advancing knowledge and skill in the area of data sharing and analytics, ensuring a lasting impact on both the academic and professional communities.
